conclusion: Analyze the motion of the electron as it is accelerated by the electric field between the cylinders.
Determine the velocity of the electron as it enters cylinder 1 and analyze its motion until it exits cylinder 2.
Determine the length of the nth metal cylinder.
The electron starts from rest at the center of the metal plate (numbered 0) and is accelerated by the electric field between the plate and cylinder 1.
The potential difference between the plate and cylinder 1 is U.
The work done by the electric field on the electron is equal to the change in its kinetic energy: eU = (1/2)mv1^2.
Solving for v1: v1 = sqrt(2eU/m).
The electron enters cylinder 1 with velocity v1 and travels through it.
Since the electric field inside the cylinder is zero, the electron moves with constant velocity v1 through cylinder 1.
When the electron exits cylinder 1, it enters the gap between cylinder 1 and cylinder 2.
The potential difference between cylinder 1 and cylinder 2 is -U (since the polarity of the AC power supply has reversed).
The electron is again accelerated by the electric field in the gap.
The work done by the electric field on the electron in the gap is: -eU = (1/2)mv2^2 - (1/2)mv1^2.
Solving for v2: v2 = sqrt(2eU/m).
The electron enters cylinder 2 with velocity v2 and travels through it with constant velocity v2.
The time for the electron to pass through the gaps between cylinders is neglected.
The electron spends half of the period T of the AC power supply in each cylinder.
The length of the nth metal cylinder is given by: Ln = vn * (T/2).
For the first cylinder, v1 = sqrt(2eU/m), so: L1 = sqrt(2eU/m) * (T/2).
For the second cylinder, v2 = sqrt(2eU/m), so: L2 = sqrt(2eU/m) * (T/2).
